SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: At the end of the second paragraph, what is the meaning of the phrase “castle in the air”?

Key.Rationale: The examples of comforts that Jo wishes to give her family and herself are dreams or fantasies.
This choice is not supported by context clues in the paragraph and the phrase “castle in the air.”
This choice is not supported by context clues in the paragraph and the phrase “castle in the air.”
This choice is not supported by context clues in the paragraph and the phrase “castle in the air.”

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What does the word c͟o͟n͟c͟o͟c͟t͟e͟d mean as it is used in the passage?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not the correct meaning of “concocted” and does not make sense in the given context.
“Invented” is the meaning of “concocted,” as it is used to signal that Jo is the creator of her tale.
This choice is not the correct meaning of “concocted” and does not make sense in the given context.
This choice is not the correct meaning of “concocted” and does not make sense in the given context.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:box:“The gentleman advanced, with a nod, and a c͟o͟u͟n͟t͟e͟n͟a͟n͟c͟e expressive of nothing but sleep.”
What does the word c͟o͟u͟n͟t͟e͟n͟a͟n͟c͟e mean as it is used in the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not reflect the correct meaning of “countenance” and does not make sense in the given context.
This choice does not reflect the correct meaning of “countenance” and does not make sense in the given context.
“Countenance” refers to one's facial appearance.
This choice does not reflect the correct meaning of “countenance” and does not make sense in the given context.

Topics: Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Determine how the author uses the meaning of words or phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings, in a text; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.

:box:“While she blushed and blundered, Mr. Dashwood had taken the manuscript, and was turning over the leaves with a pair of rather dirty fingers, and casting critical glances up and down the neat pages.”
How does the author's choice of words in the sentence affect the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: It emphasizes Jo's fear about being in an unfamiliar place.

Key.Rationale: Jo does not have fear from being in an office.

B.Choice: It emphasizes Jo's uncertainty about being a good writer.

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support the idea that Jo is uncertain about her own ability as a writer.

C.Choice: It emphasizes the power that the editor exerts over Jo.

Key.Rationale: The editor has not exerted any power over Jo at this point.

D.Choice: It emphasizes the tension of the moment for Jo.

Key.Rationale: The words “blushed,” “blundered,” and “casting critical glances” suggest that Jo feels stress from the editor evaluating her work.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
What does the passage reveal about Mr. Dashwood?

Key.Rationale: Mr. Dashwood portrays none of these traits.
Though there is some evidence to suggest Mr. Dashwood is tired and is receiving many submissions, these are minor details in the passage and are not clearly stated.

C.Choice: He is demanding and somewhat bored.

Key.Rationale: Mr. Dashwood portrays none of these traits.

D.Choice: He is practical and somewhat arrogant.

Key.Rationale: Mr. Dashwood is practical in that he wishes to print stories that sell well; he is arrogant since he laughs at Jo for her use of the phrase “my friend.”

Content: Which sentences from the passage support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “ 'The tale will be out next week...' ”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the idea that Mr. Dashwood is practical and arrogant.
The phrase “morals don't sell nowadays” supports the idea Mr. Dashwood cares about the practical matter of making money by selling stories that people will buy.

C.Choice: “ '... you can leave it, if you like.' ”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the idea that Mr. Dashwood is practical and arrogant.

D.Choice: “...'Poor and proud, as usual, but she'll do.' ”

Key.Rationale: The phrase “she'll do” suggests that Mr. Dashwood is arrogant by judging the worth of Jo as writer.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which evidence from the passage best supports the inference that Jo is determined to succeed?

A.Choice: “... money and power, therefore, she resolved to have...”

Key.Rationale: The words “resolved to have” indicate Jo's commitment to achieving success.
Even though this option show how Jo attempts to succeed, it do not support that she is determined to succeed.

C.Choice: “ '... she has had some experience, and got a prize for a tale...' ”

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to Jo's determination to succeed.
Even though this option show how Jo attempts to succeed, it do not support that she is determined to succeed.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which theme is most developed through the interaction between Jo and Mr. Dashwood?

Key.Rationale: The meeting with Mr. Dashwood was planned and no evidence suggests a tone of surprise.

B.Choice: Compromises are sometimes necessary to reach an objective.

Key.Rationale: Jo must consent to her story being significantly revised in order for it to be published.

C.Choice: Important knowledge can be gained from difficult experiences.

Key.Rationale: Though Jo gains knowledge from the revisions, this is a detail of the passage, not the theme.

D.Choice: Questionable methods are acceptable as long as the outcome is worthwhile.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not developed through the interaction between Jo and Mr. Dashwood.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “Abe Buys a Barrel,” the author focuses on Abe's interactions with many of the other characters in the drama. Write an essay analyzing how these interactions reveal specific characteristics of Abe. Use evidence from the drama to support your response.

SubTopics: Vary sentence patterns for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:box:(1) Along the old pioneer trails in the West, you will find a huge rock that looks like the back of a turtle's shell. (2) During the 1800s, pioneers—many from eastern states like Pennsylvania—would anxiously await the day they would arrive at this special landmark. (3) They knew that if they arrived there by Independence Day, then they would likely be able to make it to California and Oregon before the winter storms began to arrive. (4) Independence Day is the Fourth of July. (5) Because of this, the landmark was named Independence Rock.
Which revision that combines sentences 3 and 4 into one sentence best improves the logical relationship between the two sentences?

A.Choice: The Fourth of July, Independence Day, was when they arrived in California and Oregon before the winter storms began to arrive.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not preserve the meaning of the original sentences.

B.Choice: Independence Day, to California and Oregon, is where the pioneers wanted to be by the Fourth of July so they could avoid the winter storms.

Key.Rationale: The order of events in the sentence is unclear, resulting in a loss of meaning.

C.Choice: Arriving by Independence Day, they knew that they would be able to make it to California and Oregon before the winter storms began to arrive on the Fourth of July.

Key.Rationale: The order of events in the sentence is unclear, resulting in a loss of meaning.

D.Choice: They knew that if they arrived there by Independence Day, the Fourth of July, then they would likely be able to make it to California and Oregon before the winter storms began to arrive.

Key.Rationale: This choice concisely revises the events of the sentences in a logistical order that preserves their original meaning and contains all of the original information.

SubTopics: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.
Content: Read the sentence.
:box:After the apartment manager received many complaints from tenants, a builder was hired by her to design a new entrance to the apartment complex.
Without changing the meaning of the sentence, which is the best way to rewrite the sentence using only active voice?

A.Choice: After many complaints from tenants were received by the manager of the apartment complex, she hired a builder to design a new entrance to the apartment complex.

Key.Rationale: The dependent clause is written in the passive voice.

B.Choice: After the manager of the apartment complex received many complaints from tenants, she was hired by a builder to design a new entrance to the apartment complex.

Key.Rationale: The independent clause is written in the passive voice and the revision changes the meaning of the original sentence.

C.Choice: After the apartment manager received many complaints from tenants, she hired a builder to design a new entrance to the apartment complex.

Key.Rationale: Both independent and dependent clauses are written in the active voice and the revision maintains the meaning of the original sentence.

D.Choice: After many complaints from the manager were received by tenants, a builder was hired to design a new entrance to the apartment complex.

Key.Rationale: Both the independent and dependent clauses are written in the passive voice and the revision changes the meaning of the original sentence.

Content: Read the sentences from a paragraph.

:box:(1) While hot cereals like porridge or oatmeal have been popular in Europe for centuries, cold cereals that are packaged for quick and easy use are the invention of American entrepreneurs. (2) Two such pioneers were Charles Post and W. K. Kellogg, whose companies were founded in Battle Creek, Michigan k͟n͟o͟w͟n͟ ͟a͟t͟ ͟o͟n͟e͟ ͟t͟i͟m͟e͟ ͟a͟s͟ ͟t͟h͟e͟ ͟c͟a͟p͟i͟t͟a͟l͟ ͟o͟f͟ ͟c͟e͟r͟e͟a͟l͟ ͟p͟r͟o͟d͟u͟c͟t͟i͟o͟n. (3) Their companies developed several varieties, such as corn flakes and crisped rice.
Choose the correct way to punctuate sentence 2 to most effectively emphasize the underlined information.

A.Choice: Two such pioneers were Charles Post and W. K. Kellogg, whose companies were founded in Battle Creek, Michigan, “known at one time as the capital of cereal production.”

Key.Rationale: Quotation marks are not used for emphasis, but to give credit to a source.

B.Choice: Two such pioneers were Charles Post and W. K. Kellogg, whose companies were founded in Battle Creek, Michigan (known at one time as the capital of cereal production).

Key.Rationale: Parentheses are used to de-emphasize information.

C.Choice: Two such pioneers were Charles Post and W. K. Kellogg, whose companies were founded in Battle Creek, Michigan—known at one time as the capital of cereal production.

Key.Rationale: The use of the em dash emphasizes the information that comes after it.

D.Choice: Two such pioneers were Charles Post and W. K. Kellogg, whose companies were founded in Battle Creek, Michigan, known at one time as the capital of cereal production.

Key.Rationale: The use of commas is not as emphatic as the use of the em dash.

SubTopics: Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Content: Read the paragraph from an essay about Alexander Hamilton.

:box:(1) Alexander Hamilton served as secretary of the treasury in the cabinet of President George Washington. (2) One of his challenges was to come up with a way to get more cash for the United States. (3) His plan included establishing the credit of the new nation. (4) He also needed people to invest in a central bank that would keep the funds of the government secure.
Which sentence should be revised to maintain the formal style of the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice maintains the formal language of the paragraph.
The use of the phrase “come up with a way to get more cash” is informal language.
This choice maintains the formal language of the paragraph.
This choice maintains the formal language of the paragraph.
